por.por_cntn:
It is a well known point of view after Klein, Hilbert, Einstein and Weil that fundamental laws describe symmetries occurring in the nature. The symmetry of an object can be measured by the group corresponding to the object. Various physical systems, such as crystals or the hydrogen atom, can be analyzed through symmetry groups. Thus, group theory has many applications in physics and chemistry, ranging from the standard model of subatomic particles to cryptography.
Groups can be defined either as groups of symmetries or abstractly by an algorithmic description (generators and relations). In the second approach, the investigators choose some basic symmetries (generators) so that all other symmetries are compositions of the basic ones, and describe certain relations between the basic symmetries such that all other relations follow from the chosen ones.
The geometry of groups given by such presentations is described in terms of certain asymptotic invariants. Although the invariants have been known since the pioneering works of M.Dehn at the beginning of the 20th century, the investigatorsobtained the description of those invariants called Dehn functions. (This description is complete provided the non-deterministic computation complexity NP is equivalent to the deterministic P. The equality NP=P is the famous 'millenium conjecture'.)
The investigators obtained the complete descriptionsof Dehn functions that gaurantee the algorithmic solution of the classical conjugacy problem in groups. (The conjugacy problem is equivalent tothe question whether two closed paths given in a topological space can be continuously transformedinto each other or not.)
To obtain the main results the PIs applied methods and ideas from geometry, combinatorics, logic and computer science. However the main tools of their research were geometrical. In particular, they used the techniques of Van Kampen diagrams developed earlier by their predecessors and by themselves. In contrast to the classical Cartesian approach, where algebra is applied to geometry, they use geometric method to analyze algebraic relations.
Among the other results, the PIs would like to distinguish the absolutely new class of residually finite groups. (One can use finite groups to solve algorithmic problems in residually finite groups.) Answering a long-standing question, Sapir proved (with Kharlampovich and Myasnikov) that the complexity of the word problem in residually finite groups can be arbitrary high.
Broader impact of the work of the PIs include memberships in editorial boards of several major mathematics jurnals, support of  6 PhD students and 2 postdoctoral fellows working under the supervision of the PIs, 30 plenary talks of PIs at international conferences during 2015-19, and preparation of many conferences.
